oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Suffrage Would Mean Clean and Unpurchashable Votes." The Memphis News-Scimitar prints the following letter received by the editor of the woman's page from Mrs. George Randolph in regard to woman's suffrage. "A republican form of government is lasting and stable only so long as the majority of votes cast are honest votes. The many political scandals unearthed in recent years prove that the number of bought or controlled votes has steadily increased since the early days of the republic. "The votes of women are opposed among others by the liquor interests, by the 'big business' manufacturers who now weave the souls of women and chil- dren into costly fabrics, and by all who exploit women and babies. The reason for their opposition is that they fear the stand women will take when they or- ganize, and vote, and that only by their united action can the opinions of women crystalize into power. "Few women who have the mother in- stinct would cast a vote other than for what they believe to be for the best in- terest of their children and fireside. Suf- frage would mean clean and unpurchas- able votes and our government needs a[ll] such. "The woman movement at work as over the world today stands for honesty, humanity, progress, good government."
